div.p: Greetings. I greatly wished, but was unable, to write very lengthy letters to you, most distinguished Bullinger. The Jesuits are now moving to Munich, otherwise occupying the splendid nest of Ingolstadt; their task is to manage the literary school not only in Munich but also throughout all of Bavaria under the leadership of Staphylus. I see that unless the Lord is present with a mighty hand, papistic errors will grow more severe and worsen day by day. A large part of the blame lies with the mute, tongue-tied, and idle dogs, who, due to their gluttony, prioritize their stomachs in the greatest public matters.
Canisius preaches here in the cathedral church; without a doubt, he is up to something. I give eternal thanks for Jeremiah.

Someone wrote to me, as this document shows; if you can help, I ask you to do so. Neogeorgus is said to have written an excellent poem against the Catalog of Heretics condemned by the Pope. Do not pay anything to the courier.
To Heinrich Bullinger, theologian and friend, to be honored with the utmost reverence.
